awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Market Power and Resource Allocation
awd_abstract_narration:
Most discussion of the social cost of market power focuses on the harm to consumers, with little focus on the extent to which production can be distorted. However, market power and especially cartelization can be a significant source of production misallocation. This project aims at measuring this effect in an important setting -- the global market for crude oil, in which the OPEC cartel, the largest cartel currently in existence, is active. Over the course of history, OPEC has allocated production to members via a quota system. One effect of this quota system is to shift output from low cost producers to high cost producers. By exploiting a comprehensive data of global oil producing assets, this project will produce precise estimates of the global costs of this production distortion. Therefore, this research will enrich public understanding of the global costs of the current structure of the global oil market, and better inform microeconomic policies on the relative costs of market power. 

This project aims to investigate the extent to which market power can be an important source of production misallocation. This research will engage with existing literatures in the fields of Macroeconomics and Industrial Organization that seek to understand the sources of differential performance across countries and industries. The setting is the global oil market. Using a comprehensive global data set of oil producing assets, the investigators will first measure covariances between observed production costs and market shares, because variation in these measures can be shown to reflect variation in misallocation over time. The investigators will then adopt a more structural econometric approach to estimate asset-specific cost functions and further aggregate them to form an industry supply function. This will allow current allocations to be compared to the allocations that would occur in a perfectly competitive model, hence providing a static quantification of misallocation on a year-by-year basis. This static measure will then be adjusted to account for the dynamic extraction problem embodied in the oil production process, which will be addressed by adapting existing computational oligopoly methods from Industrial Organization.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to understand the impact of market power in the global oil industry. 


As part of this project, two papers were produced. The first, entitled, "(Mis)Allocation, Market Power, and Global Oil Extraction" was published in the American Economic Review. The second, "The Welfare Effects of Market Power: the OPEC Cartel" is a working paper. 


The first paper shows that oil production displaced from low cost OPEC members, such as Saudi Arabia, to higher cost locations, such as far more expensive shale produced in the United States or offshore oil extraction in Norway. The welfare losses from this misallocation in production, rather than any issues on how much oil should be produced globally (which is held fixed), are on the order of US$744 billion from 1970 to 2014. We call this failure of production to be allocated in a cost minimizing way, "productive innefficiency". Of this number, 14.1 percent to 21.9 percent is attributable to market power.


The second paper, entitled "The Welfare Impact of Market Power: The OPEC Cartel". The paper assess the welfare losses due to market power including both the productive inefficiency documented in our first paper and deadweight losses due to variation in prices due to market power. Importantly, this exercise requires us to think more carefully about what the competitive equilibrium would look like in a non-renewable resource market, and we develop new theoretical and computational tools to solve this problem. We find that the deadweight losses due to market power are 6 trillion dollars from 1970 to 2014. Moreover, the deadweight losses are an order of magnitude larger than the productive inefficiencies alone.

There are three results that are important achievements for this project. First, we have opened up new datasets looking at field level data for oil production across the world. Previous studies either used global data that was aggregated to the level of a country, or very specific geographic data, such as extensive work on say the oil industry in North Dakota. This type of data allows for both a granular understanding of costs and production choices with field level information, while the global scope of the data also allows us to think about market equilibrium and prices for the oil industry. Second, we have documented a pattern of extensive cost dispersion in the oil industry, with the 90th percentile of production costing about ten times more than the 10th percentile. This dispersion in costs was also shown to correlate with known features of the operation of the OPEC cartel, with countries such as Saudi Arabia having low costs of oil production and choosing not to expand production, in contrast, say, to producers in the United States. Third, we have worked on tools to decompose this dispersion in costs into the components that can be attributed to market power versus not. In particular, some of this decomposition involves computing models of dynamic extraction choices in the oil industry which have to account for the non-renewable nature of the resource. 

There is a sustained interest in understanding the antitrust implications of cartel. More narrowly, OPEC is the world's largest cartel, but there is limited work in understanding the impact of the cartel. From a broader perspective, most work in antitrust has focused on the consumer surplus impacts of cartels; i.e., how higher prices affect consumers. Our work on global oil production opens up the perspective that cartels also lead to economic inefficiencies in production. Furthermore, the operation of the OPEC cartel is aided by other inefficiencies in the production of oil in non-OPEC countries. Thus, there is natural complementarity between frictions in production from a competitive fringe and the operation of a cartel. 

 


Last Modified: 10/26/2021
Modified by: Allan Collard-Wexler
